In Julia, Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.

Here is the Julia code for your problem:

```julia
using DataFrames, Dates

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = map(x -> Dates.year(x)*100 + Dates.month(x), df.dt)
    return df
end
```
This function `add_yearmonth` takes a DataFrame as input and adds a new column `ym` to it which is the concatenation of year and month from `dt`. The `map` function applies a function (in this case, extracting year and month) to every element in the column `dt`, and then the result is added to the new column `ym`.

You can use this function like:
```julia
df = DataFrame(dt=DateTime[now() + Month(i) for i in 1:5])
add_yearmonth(df)
```
